properties.name: Platformer PickUp
properties.description:
A platformer game where up to 4 players work together to collect all of the coins.

This game example includes:
-Multiplayer lobby
-Platformer behavior
-Rectangular movement behavior
-Sound effects
-Text objects
-Timers

events.comment: Reseting the global GameLevel variable
Lobby opening and game start
Beginning of scene - level select
Beginning of scene - game set-up
Giving ownership to respective players
When a player joins, a new Player will be created. Deactivate its Camera behavior.
Make the username follow the player
Game reset
Lobby end

events.name: Player coin pick up and pitch increase

events.comment: Game end
Next level

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SpriteMultitouchJoystick
description: Multitouch joysticks can be used the same way as physical gamepads:
- 4 or 8 directions
- Analogus pads
- Player selection
- Controls mapping for top-down movement and platformer characters
There are ready-to-use joysticks in the asset-store [multitouch joysticks pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=multitouch-joysticks-multitouch-joysticks).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object. This action must be called after the object has moved for the frame.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCameraCloser

events.comment: The camera following is called with an action, the call from doStepPreEvents must be disabled to avoid to do it twice.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object.
eventsFunctions.name: DoMoveCameraCloser

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Delay the camera according to a maximum speed and catch up the delay.
eventsFunctions.name: WaitAndCatchUp
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delay the camera of _PARAM0_ during: _PARAM2_ seconds according to the maximum speed _PARAM3_;_PARAM4_ seconds and catch up in _PARAM5_ seconds

events.comment: Maybe the catch-up show be done in constant pixel speed instead of constant time speed.

eventsFunctions.description: Update delayed position and delayed history. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateDelayedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

eventsFunctions.name: AddForecastHistoryPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Add the time:_PARAM2_ and position: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_ to the forecast history of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX)²)
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY)²)
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a² + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a² + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ForecastTimeRatio

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ButtonStates
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Use any object as a button and change appearance according to user interactions.
description: Use the "Button states" behavior to track user interactions with an object, including:
- Hovered
- Pressed
- Clicked
- Idle
Add additional behaviors to make juicy buttons with animated responses to user input:
- Size
- Color
- Animation
- Object effects

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PlatformerCharacterAnimator
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Change animations and horizontal flipping of a platformer character automatically.
description: Automatically change the animations and horizontal flipping of a platformer character based on movement and interaction with platform objects.
The platformer example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RectangleMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move objects in a rectangular pattern.
description: Move objects in a rectangular pattern with easing functions from the Tween extension.
It can be used for:
- Moveable platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
- Moving along the border of another object (inside, center, outside)
The platformer example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer)).
This game shows how to make objects move around the border of another object ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://moving-saw-platformer)).
This example can be used to test different settings ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://rectangular-movement)).

eventsFunctions.description: Distance from an object to the closest edge of a second object.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Distance from an object to the closest edge of a second object
eventsFunctions.name: DistanceToClosestEdge
eventsFunctions.sentence: Distance from _PARAM1_ to the closest edge of _PARAM2_

events.comment: If point is inside rectangle, just use min distance

parameters:
min(
min(
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY() - CenterObject.BoundingBoxTop(), 
CenterObject.BoundingBoxBottom() - MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY()),
min(
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX() - CenterObject.BoundingBoxLeft(), 
CenterObject.BoundingBoxRight() - MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX())
)

events.comment: If point is outside rectangle, find distance to clamped position on rectangle

parameters:
DistanceBetweenPositions(
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX(),
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY(),
clamp(MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxLeft(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxRight()),
clamp(MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxTop(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxBottom())
)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.description: Reset the state of the button.
eventsFunctions.name: ResetState

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is not used.
eventsFunctions.name: IsIdle

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button was just clicked.
eventsFunctions.name: IsClicked

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the cursor is hovered over the button.
eventsFunctions.name: IsHovered

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is either hovered or pressed but not hovered.
eventsFunctions.name: IsFocused

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressed

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed outside with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressedOutside

eventsFunctions.description: the touch id that is using the button or 0 if none.
eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsBasedObjects.description: A button that can be customized.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.
